Explanations about Options.-n(C): use the "head" command, which prints the first n lines of some output: .  "ls -t" outputs the current directory sorted by time. "head -n 5" takes the first five entries of the previous output. use the "tail" command to print lines starting with the n th line (Option "-n +N"): .  "ls -t" outputs the current directory sorted by time. "tail -n +6" takes al lines starting with the 6th line.
Explanations about Options.-n(M):
print the first NUM lines instead of the first 10; with the leading '-', print all
 but the last NUM lines of each file

Answers.MP Summary: output the first part of files
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Output everything but the last few lines of a file
Top-3 Scripts:
au_685796: mylast () {
        re='^[0-9]+$'
        if ! [[ $1 =~ $re ]] ; then
           echo "error: $1 not a number" >&2
        else
           history | awk '{a[$2]++} END {for (i in a) print a[i], i}' | sort -rn | head -n $1
        fi
}
